# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session
source.ba83b4de:
import os
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import requests
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline

from datetime import timedelta

# Combining several CSV files
from glob import glob 

# hide warnings
import warnings
warnings.simplefilter('ignore')
source.4b98e4ea:
## using glob function to combine several CSV files with same strucure
files = sorted (glob('../input/wine-quality-red/winequality-*.csv'))
files
source.b755cf1a:
# using concat to combined all files and assign() methods
wine_df = pd.concat((pd.read_csv(file, sep=';').assign(color = file) for file in files), ignore_index = True)
wine_df
source.adfbd650:
# modify file path to color column.

wine_df.color = wine_df.color.str.replace('../input/wine-quality-red/winequality-', '')
wine_df.color = wine_df.color.str.replace('.csv', '')

wine_df.head()
source.b6f0e4e8:
# add"_" to column names
wine_df = wine_df.rename(columns = {'fixed acidity' :'fixed_acidity', 'volatile acidity' :'volatile_acidity', 'citric acid' :'citric_acid',
                                    'residual sugar' :'residual_sugar', 'free sulfur dioxide' :'free_sulfur_dioxide',
                                    'total sulfur dioxide' :'total_sulfur_dioxide'})
wine_df.head()
source.d715cbc8:
# save "wine_df" dataframe in CSV format at new created folder(gathering_data)
wine_df.to_csv('/kaggle/working/wine_df.csv', index=False)
source.5cf2f2a5:
sns.set_style('darkgrid')
wine_df.groupby('color')['quality'].mean().plot(kind = 'bar', color = ['red','white'])
plt.title('Average Wine Quality By Color')
plt.xlabel('Colors', fontsize=18)
plt.ylabel('Quality', fontsize=18)
plt.show();
source.1c2bfd4e:
# plot per category for red & white wines
counts = wine_df.groupby(['quality', 'color']).count()
counts
source.288f3333:
# while all categories are the same so we need choose any one like "pH"
counts = wine_df.groupby(['color', 'quality']).count().pH
counts
source.9b3c84a7:
# Plot count
sns.set_style('darkgrid')
counts.plot(kind = 'bar', color = ['red','white'], figsize = (18,10))
plt.title('Counts by Wine Color and Quality')
plt.xlabel('Quality & Color', fontsize=18)
plt.ylabel('Count', fontsize=18)
plt.show();
source.bcc92e0e:
# devide each count by total count for each color
totals = wine_df.groupby('color').count().pH
totals
source.0378babb:
# Get Red Proportions
red_proportions = counts.red / totals.red
red_proportions
source.88366ed6:
# we're missing a red wine value for the 9 rating, it should = 0
red_proportions['9'] = 0

red_proportions
source.1c689a57:
# Get White Proportions
white_proportions = counts.white / totals.white
white_proportions
source.dfb4e4bd:
# the X locations for the group
x= np.arange(len(red_proportions)) 

# the width of the bars
width = 0.35
source.eba47bae:
# Plot proportions
fig,ax = plt.subplots (figsize = (18,10))
plt.bar(x = x, height = red_proportions, width = width, color = 'red', label ='Red Wine')
ax.bar(x = x, height = white_proportions, width = width*0.5, color = 'white', label ='White Wine')
plt.title('proportions by Wine Color and Quality')
plt.xlabel('Quality', fontsize=18)
plt.ylabel('proportions', fontsize=18)

# xticks locations
locations = x + width/2
labels = ['3','4','5','6','7','8','9'] # xticks labels
plt.xticks(locations, labels)
plt.legend()
plt.show();
source.4c5f0609:
# using describe function to get requied renges
wine_df.describe().pH
source.bca51e60:
# Bin edges that will be used to "cut" the data into groups
bin_edges = [2.72, 3.11, 3.21, 3.33, 4.01] # min, 25%, 50%, 75%, max

# Labels for the four acidity level groups
bin_names = ['High', 'Mod_High', 'Medium', 'Low'] # Name each acidity level category.
source.c7c7c23e:
# Creates "acidity_levels" column
wine_df['acidity_levels'] = pd.cut(wine_df.pH, bin_edges, labels = bin_names)

#check column creation successful
wine_df.head()
source.87e066ba:
# Get the mean quality for each acidity level

acidity_level_quality_means = wine_df.groupby('acidity_levels').quality.mean()
acidity_level_quality_means
source.d696c471:
# plot Bar chart
plt.bar(x = [4,3,2,1],height = acidity_level_quality_means, tick_label = acidity_level_quality_means.index.str.title())
plt.title('Average Quality Ratings by Acidity Level')
plt.xlabel('Acidity Level')
plt.ylabel('Average Quality Rating')
plt.show();
source.f3f00b34:
# Get low_alcohol < median
low_alcohol = wine_df.query('alcohol < alcohol.median()')

# Get high_alcohol >= median
high_alcohol = wine_df.query('alcohol >= alcohol.median()')
source.3b6a0957:
# Check this queries included each sample exactly once
wine_df.shape[0] == low_alcohol.quality.count() + high_alcohol.quality.count()

mean_quality_high = high_alcohol.quality.mean()

plt.ylabel('Average Quality Rating')
plt.show();

source.34be4935: > **Sweeter Wines generally receive higher rating(high_residual).**
source.5167e8cd: **Q8: Do wines with total_sulfur_dioxide(SO2) content receive better ratings?** > `Total sulfur dioxide`: is the sum of the bound and the free sulfur dioxide (SO2). Here, it’s expressed in mg/dm3dm3. There are legal limits for sulfur levels in wines: in the EU, red wines can only have 160mg/L, while white and rose wines can have about 210mg/L. 1. we need to create 2 groups of Red Wine samples: > * __low_red_SO2__ ==> samples with total_sulfur_dioxide content `<` 160 > * __high_red_SO2__ ==> samples with total_sulfur_dioxide content `>=` 160 2. we need to create 2 groups of White Wine samples: > * __low_white_SO2__ ==> samples with total_sulfur_dioxide content `<` 210 > * __high_white_SO2__ ==> samples with total_sulfur_dioxide content `>=` 210 2. then get `mean quality` rating for * Red Wine: low_red_SO2 & high_red_SO2 * White Wine: low_white_SO2 & high_white_SO2
source.809f12b4: **Q5: Do wines with higher citric_acid content receive better ratings?** 1. we need to create 2 groups of wine samples: > * __low_acid__ ==> samples with citric_acid content `<` the median > * __high_acid__ ==> samples with citric_acid content `>=` the median 2. then get `mean quality` rating for low_acid & high_acid
source.3a415621: **Q6: Do wines with higher density content receive better ratings?** 1. we need to create 2 groups of wine samples: > * __low_density__ ==> samples with density content `<` the median > * __high_density__ ==> samples with density content `>=` the median 2. then get `mean quality` rating for low_density & high_density
source.67f5625a: > **Higher alcohol content generally receive better rating(high_alcohol).**
source.f147b4d4: **Q1: Is a certain type of wine (red or white) associated with higher quality?**
source.78291e69: > **White Wine have Higer Quality than Red Wine.**
source.b44b2435: (Wine Quality - red or white?) Wine quality data set from the UCI Machine Learning Repository [Wine Quality - red or white?](https://www.kaggle.com/xuzihe2010/wine-quality-red) by (Peter Gamal Girgis) **Task Details:** > About the Dataset > __Feature introduction__: > >> `Fixed acidity`: acids are major wine properties and contribute greatly to the wine’s taste. Usually, the total acidity is divided into two groups: the volatile acids and the nonvolatile or fixed acids. Among the fixed acids that you can find in wines are the following: tartaric, malic, citric, and succinic.This variable is expressed in g(tartaricacidtartaricacid)/dm3dm3 in the data sets. >> >> `Volatile acidity`: the volatile acidity is basically the process of wine turning into vinegar. In the U.S, the legal limits of Volatile Acidity are 1.2 g/L for red table wine and 1.1 g/L for white table wine. In these data sets, the volatile acidity is expressed in g(aceticacidaceticacid)/dm3dm3. >> >>Citric acid is one of the fixed acids that you’ll find in wines. It’s expressed in g/dm3dm3 in the two data sets. >> >>Residual sugar typically refers to the sugar remaining after fermentation stops, or is stopped. It’s expressed in g/dm3dm3 in the red and white data. >> >> Chlorides can be a major contributor to saltiness in wine. Here, you’ll see that it’s expressed in g(sodiumchloridesodiumchloride)/dm3dm3. >> >> `Free sulfur dioxide`: the part of the sulphur dioxide that is added to a wine and that is lost into it is said to be bound, while the active part is said to be free. Winemaker will always try to get the highest proportion of free sulphur to bind. This variables is expressed in mg/dm3dm3 in the data. >> >>Total sulfur dioxide is the sum of the bound and the free sulfur dioxide (SO2). Here, it’s expressed in mg/dm3dm3. There are legal limits for sulfur levels in wines: in the EU, red wines can only have 160mg/L, while white and rose wines can have about 210mg/L. Sweet wines are allowed to have 400mg/L. For the US, the legal limits are set at 350mg/L and for Australia, this is 250mg/L. >> >>Density is generally used as a measure of the conversion of sugar to alcohol. Here, it’s expressed in g/cm3cm3. pH or the potential of hydrogen is a numeric scale to specify the acidity or basicity the wine. As you might know, solutions with a pH less than 7 are acidic, while solutions with a pH greater than 7 are basic. With a pH of 7, pure water is neutral. Most wines have a pH between 2.9 and 3.9 and are therefore acidic. >> >>Sulphates are to wine as gluten is to food. You might already know sulphites from the headaches that they can cause. They are a regular part of the winemaking around the world and are considered necessary. In this case, they are expressed in g(potassiumsulphatepotassiumsulphate)/dm3dm3. >> >> `Alcohol`: wine is an alcoholic beverage and as you know, the percentage of alcohol can vary from wine to wine. It shouldn’t surprised that this variable is inclued in the data sets, where it’s expressed in % vol. >> >> `Quality`: wine experts graded the wine quality between 0 (very bad) and 10 (very excellent). The eventual number is the median of at least three evaluations made by those same wine experts.
source.e82579b6: **Q4: Do sweeter wines (more residual sugar) receive better ratings?** 1. we need to create 2 groups of wine samples: > * __low_residual__ ==> samples with residual_suger content `<` the median > * __high_residual__ ==> samples with residual_suger content `>=` the median 2. then get `mean quality` rating for low_residual & high_residual
source.bafbd8b9: **Q2: Which level of acidity (pH value) receives the highest average rating?** > we can get Acidity levels related below levels: >> 1. __High__ ==> Lowest __`0% - 25%`__ of PH Values. >> 2. __Moderately Hgih__ ==> __`25% - 50%`__ of PH Values. >> 3. __Medium__ ==> __`50% - 75%`__ of PH Values.>> >> 4. __Low__ ==> __`75% - 100%`__ of PH Values.
source.be190da8: > **citric_acid Wines generally receive higher rating(low_density).**
source.417427c3: **Q7: Do wines with higher volatile_acidity(vinegar) content receive better ratings?** > `Volatile acidity`: the volatile acidity is basically the process of wine turning into vinegar. In the U.S, the legal limits of Volatile Acidity are 1.2 g/L for red table wine and 1.1 g/L for white table wine. In these data sets, the volatile acidity is expressed in g(aceticacidaceticacid)/dm3dm3. 1. we need to create 2 groups of Red Wine samples: > * __low_red_vineger__ ==> samples with volatile_acidity content `<` 1.2 > * __high_red_vineger__ ==> samples with volatile_acidity content `>=` 1.2 2. we need to create 2 groups of White Wine samples: > * __low_white_vineger__ ==> samples with volatile_acidity content `<` 1.1 > * __high_white_vineger__ ==> samples with volatile_acidity content `>=` 1.1 2. then get `mean quality` rating for * Red Wine: low_red_vineger & high_red_vineger * White Wine: low_white_vineger & high_white_vineger
